author: Brendan Boyle
title: ‘How to Die’ Review: Finish With a Flourish
text:
In A.D. 65 the emperor Nero forced Seneca, the Roman philosopher and statesman and Nero’s erstwhile tutor, to commit suicide. Calmly and fearlessly, the historian Tacitus recounts, Seneca cut open the veins in his arms. This didn’t work. So he tried the veins of his shins and knees. This, too, left him standing. He drank hemlock, but his body was too cold for the poison to take effect. Undeterred, he entered a hot bath and, after making an offering to Jupiter the Liberator, was at last done in by the poison and the steam.
...
